title: Sampler, 1810
medium:
Medium: silk embroidery on cotton foundation
Technique: embroidered in cross and eyelet stitches on plain weave foundation
description: Alphabet, crowned monograms, and field of assorted motifs within an acorn vine.
justification:
Griet Ruwen’s sampler shows how deeply ingrained faith and religion were in daily Dutch culture in the early nineteenth century.&nbsp; Even as she practiced her needlework, Griet expressed piety and religious devotion through symbolism.
Below the crowns and initials are two angels holding a wreath of roses, representing eternity, encircling a dove, a symbol of mercy and peace. In the center a line of three animals is repeated symmetrically on each side:&nbsp; a hart, representing gentleness and pride, a dove, again a symbol of mercy and peace, and a dog, symbolizing fidelity and watchfulness.&nbsp; Close to the borders on each side are the Spies of Canaan, represented by two men with a cluster of grapes between them.&nbsp; The grapes represent Christ on the cross.&nbsp; The ladders are among the Instruments of Christ’s Passion.&nbsp; At each lower corner is a bird feeding three younger birds known as the Pious Pelican.&nbsp; This is the most common symbol relating to Christ’s sacrifice.&nbsp;

tombstone.epitaph:
Sampler, 1810.
1810. Medium: silk embroidery on cotton foundation
Technique: embroidered in cross and eyelet stitches on plain weave foundation. Bequest of Gertrude M. Oppenheimer. 1981-28-214.
